data.title: All 25 John Finnegan Movies In Order — All The Best (And Worst) Films To Watch Online
data.meta_description: Get ready for an exciting adventure through John Finnegan’s illustrious movie career! In this roundup, we delve into the captivating world of film as we take a closer look at his most notable works…
data.text:
Get ready for an exciting adventure through John Finnegan’s illustrious movie career! In this roundup, we delve into the captivating world of film as we take a closer look at his most notable works and the impact they’ve made on the industry and audiences alike.

As an Amazon Affiliate I earn from qualified purchases at no cost to you.

1. Dirty Harry (1971)

Dirty Harry, released in 1971, is a riveting action, crime, and suspense film that centers around Police Inspector Harry Callahan as he faces off against a formidable new foe known as the Scorpio Killer. This heart-pumping flick is set in the bustling city of San Francisco, which falls prey to a series of horrifying murders orchestrated by the enigmatic Scorpio. With Callahan’s unyielding no-nonsense attitude and ferocity in pursuit of justice, the stage is set for a deadly game of cat and mouse with the sly adversary who consistently manages to stay one step ahead.

👉 Stream free from Prime

2. Play It As It Lays (1972)

Experience the emotional turmoil of a Hollywood actress in the riveting drama film, “Play It As It Lays, “ released in 1973. Based on the novel by Joan Didion, this psychological masterpiece features a complex and intense portrayal of a traumatized woman who spirals into a state of psychic breakdown.

👀 View now for free from Amazon

3. Savage (1973)

In the chilling thriller, Savage, Martin Landau stars as a hard-nosed TV reporter who becomes embroiled in an investigation that uncovers shocking secrets. With a cast that also includes Barbara Bain and Will Geer, the film follows the reporter as he delves into compromising photographs of a nominee to the Supreme Court, a case that becomes increasingly complex and potentially dangerous with each new revelation.

👉 View now for free from Amazon Prime

4. Capone (1975)

Capone (1975), directed by Steve Carver and written by Howard Browne, is a biographical crime drama that portrays the life of infamous Chicago gangster Al Capone. Set during the prohibition years, the film follows Capone’s rise to power and control over the city. The movie stars Ben Gazzara as Al Capone, Susan Blakely, and Harry Guardino in supporting roles.

👀 Stream free @ Amazon

5. Nickelodeon (1976)

Nickelodeon (1976) is a light-hearted comedy film that takes us back to the early days of the film industry. Audiences will be captivated by the tale of Buck and lawyer Leo who, by accident, find themselves immersed in the world of movie production in the 1910s. As they navigate this unfamiliar territory, they encounter a plethora of challenges and humorous situations that unfold amidst the bustling film business.

📺 View for free via Amazon

6. The Lindbergh Kidnapping Case (1976)

The Lindbergh Kidnapping Case takes viewers on a thrilling journey through a dark chapter in American history, as it brings the true story of a horrifying event that shook the nation to its core. On March 1, 1932, the son of the infamous pilot, Charles Lindbergh, is abducted, sparking a nation-wide investigation filled with drama and intrigue. The Lindbergh Kidnapping Case delves into the shocking details of the trial surrounding Bruno Hauptmann, a German immigrant accused of kidnapping and murdering the child. Despite the passage of time, this chilling case still stands as a reminder of the human capacity for brutality and the lengths to which those who hold power will go to protect their own.

📺 View free @ Amazon

7. Heroes (1977)

“Heroes, “ released in 1977, follows the story of a Vietnam War veteran who struggles with post-traumatic stress disorder and seeks solace in a worm farm in California. Accompanied by a sympathetic traveler, the duo embarks on a hilarious and poignant road trip amidst the backdrop of a bygone era.

👀 Watch free from Prime

8. Bloodbrothers (1978)

“Bloodbrothers” is a gripping drama from 1978, a film that will tug at your heartstrings and keep you on the edge of your seat. Directed by Robert Mulligan and starring a stellar cast including Paul Sorvino, Tony Lo Bianco, and Richard Gere, the movie tells the story of a young man caught in the crossfire between loyalty to his brothers and the desire to chart his own destiny.

🎬 View now for free at Amazon

9. The In-Laws (1979)

Get ready for an unforgettable comedic adventure in “The In-Laws” (1979)! Directed by Arthur Hiller and featuring the star-studded cast of Peter Falk, Alan Arkin, and Richard Libertini, this film transports audiences to the bustling streets of New York City on the eve of a very special wedding.

👉 View free @ Prime

10. Little Miss Marker (1980)

Little Miss Marker, a delightful 1930s comedy film, revolves around the unexpected events that unfold in the life of a gruff bookie. The plot twists when he agrees to a bet, using a cute 6-year-old boy as the collateral. What follows is a heartwarming and adventurous journey as the child, the bookie, and the horse racing world intertwine, leading to unexpected friendships and romance.

👀 Stream now free with Prime

11. Rehearsal for Murder (1982)

“Rehearsal for Murder” is a thrilling, 1982 drama-mystery where the year of grief for the protagonist turns to a year of deadly surprises. The story follows a playwright, whose fiancée has mysteriously passed away the previous year. To make matters more complicated, the playwright discovers that his new play, which is supposedly unrelated, is being used as a trap for the deceased lover’s murderer.

🎬 Stream now free at Amazon Prime

12. The Natural (1984)

In 1984, Robert Redford starred as Roy Hobbs, an enigmatic middle-aged baseball player, in The Natural. Based on the novel by Bernard Malamud, this timeless sports drama follows the rise of Roy Hobbs, a seemingly supernatural talent, from obscurity to legend. Directed by Barry Levinson, The Natural features an all-star cast and compelling storyline that seamlessly weaves together themes of redemption, loyalty, and the pursuit of greatness.

📺 Stream now free via Amazon

13. The Journey of Natty Gann (1985)

The Journey of Natty Gann is a heartwarming and adventurous tale set in the 1930s, during the Great Depression. The story follows a strong-willed tomboy, Natty Gann, who embarks on a thrilling journey as she decides to run away from her guardian, determined to reunite with her father. Natty, disguised as a boy and joined by a loyal wolf companion, faces numerous challenges on her treacherous 2,000-mile quest.

📺 View now for free at Prime

14. An American Tail (1986)

“An American Tail” is a heartwarming animated adventure comedy, set in 19th century New York City, where a young Russian mouse named Fievel Mousekewitz is on an epic journey to reunite his family after getting separated during their journey to the United States. As Fievel navigates the challenges of life in a new country, he encounters a diverse cast of characters, including a mischievous cat, a determined record-playing mouse, and an amusing pair of street musicians who share his dream of reuniting the family. Along the way, Fievel discovers the joys of friendship, the power of music, and the importance of staying true to oneself.

👀 Stream for free on Prime

15. Big Trouble (1986)

“Big Trouble, “ released in 1986, is a riotous comedy that takes you on a wild ride with its quirky characters and unexpected twists. Directed by the legendary duo of John Cassavetes and Andrew Bergman, the film follows an insurance agent (played by Peter Falk) who hatches a murderous plot with the help of his client (Alan Arkin). But things quickly spiral out of control and the duo find themselves entangled in a web of hilarious chaos.

👀 Watch now for free with Prime

16. Conspiracy: The Trial of the Chicago 8 (1987)

“Conspiracy: The Trial of the Chicago 8” is a riveting account of the infamous Chicago Conspiracy trial in 1987. This ground-breaking docudrama transports viewers to the heart of a pivotal moment in American history, using an experimental documentary style that merges drama and documentary with chilling effectiveness.

👀 View for free from Prime

17. Finish Line (1989)

Finish Line, released in 1989, is a gripping drama and sport film that tells the story of a young athlete on the rise. Fueled by ambition, the college student pushes himself to train harder and longer, ultimately leading him to make a life-altering decision.

Watch now free via Prime

18. Come See the Paradise (1990)

“Come See the Paradise” is a poignant drama that delves into a forbidden love between an Irish-American man and a Japanese-American woman, set against the backdrop of World War II. Directed by Alan Parker and starring Dennis Quaid, Tamlyn Tomita, and Sab Shimono, the movie chronicles the couple’s passionate romance, which is ultimately threatened when the Pearl Harbor attacks force the woman into a prison camp due to her ethnicity.

👀 Watch free from Amazon Prime

19. The Last of the Finest (1990)

“The Last of the Finest” is a gripping action-packed crime drama that takes the audience on a thrilling journey through the murky underworld of drug trafficking and government corruption. Set in 1990, the film follows four LAPD officers as they vigorously fight the war on drugs, only to be betrayed by their corrupt superiors. When one member of the team is brutally assassinated, the remaining three officers are forced to quit the department and continue their relentless quest for justice on their own.

👉 Watch free at Prime

21. Last Action Hero (1993)

In the action-packed, comedic adventure “Last Action Hero” (1993), directed by John McTiernan, a young movie fan named Danny Madigan (Austin O’Brien) comes across a magic golden ticket during a screening of his favorite action hero, Jack Slater (Arnold Schwarzenegger). Unknowingly, the ticket transports him into the very world of his beloved film, where he’s paired with his hero as they embark on a thrilling quest to stop notorious villains led by Tony Vivaldi (Anthony Quinn) and Mr. Benedict (Charles Dance).

📺 Stream free with Prime

22. It’s All in the Game (1993)

In “It’s All in the Game, “ a chilling tale of betrayal and deception unfolds, as the cold-blooded murder of a two-timing lover sets the stage for an intricate game of cat and mouse. Faye Dunaway and Claudia Christian play women who take matter into their own hands, only to discover the perils of their actions. When they aren’t plotting revenge, they’re attempting to seduce the enigmatic Lieutenant Columbo, played by the legendary Peter Falk.

📺 Watch free with Amazon
